_**Still Open All Hours**_ is a [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United
Kingdom") sitcom, starring [David Jason](/wiki/David_Jason "David Jason"), a
[sequel](/wiki/Sequel "Sequel") to the series _[Open All
Hours](/wiki/Open_All_Hours "Open All Hours")_ , written by original writer
[Roy Clarke](/wiki/Roy_Clarke "Roy Clarke"). The series has run for 27
episodes in four series so far, with a fifth planned for late 2018.

_Open All Hours_ ran for 26 episodes in four series from 1973 to 1985. The BBC
announced on 7 October 2013,[1] that the show would air for a 40th Anniversary
Special in December 2013. The 40th Anniversary special aired on 26 December at
7:45pm on [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One"). [Ronnie
Barker](/wiki/Ronnie_Barker "Ronnie Barker"), who played the main character of
Arkwright, in _Open All Hours_ , died in 2005: the special featured [David
Jason](/wiki/David_Jason "David Jason")'s Granville, Arkwright's assistant and
nephew in the original series, having inherited the grocery store from
Arkwright. Other returning cast members included [Lynda
Baron](/wiki/Lynda_Baron "Lynda Baron"), [Stephanie Cole](/wiki/Stephanie_Cole
"Stephanie Cole"), and [Maggie Ollerenshaw](/wiki/Maggie_Ollerenshaw "Maggie
Ollerenshaw")

## Series development and
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Still_Open_All_Hours&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Series development and production")]

_Still Open All Hours_ was broadcast on 26 December 2013, with Jason reprising
his role of Granville from _Open All Hours_. The new one-off episode written
by Clarke showed Granville now running the shop with his son Leroy (played by
[James Baxter](/wiki/James_Baxter_\(actor\) "James Baxter \(actor\)")),[2]
after inheriting it from Arkwright.[3] Clarke wrote the script in two weeks,
and production began in October 2013. The exterior scenes were filmed at the
original location at Lister Avenue in [Doncaster](/wiki/Doncaster "Doncaster")
from 18 to 20 November 2013. The interior scenes were recorded on 3 December
2013 at [MediaCityUK](/wiki/MediaCityUK "MediaCityUK") in
[Salford](/wiki/City_of_Salford "City of Salford") in front of a studio
audience. A 30-minute documentary accompanying the show's return, entitled
_Open All Hours: A Celebration_ , aired on 27 December 2013, the day after the
new episode was broadcast, on BBC One.[4][5][6]

On 30 January 2014, the BBC commissioned _Still Open All Hours_ for six new
episodes beginning on 26 December 2014.[7][8] The controller of BBC comedy
commissioning, Shane Allen, said: "The resounding success of the Christmas
revival showed the huge and enduring audience affection for this much-loved
classic. Roy has done a terrific job of updating the characters whilst keeping
what was warm-hearted and enjoyable about the world of the original
series."[9]

Production for series one started in August 2014, exterior filming started on
15 September and location recording was completed on 26 September
2014.[10][11] Interior scenes were recorded in front of a studio audience from
10 October until 21 November 2014 at Teddington Studios.[12]

The show later returned for a second series, beginning on 26 December
2015.[13][14] with production starting in September 2015. Exterior scenes were
filmed on location from 14[15]-24 September 2015.[16] Interior scenes were
recorded in front of a studio audience at [Pinewood
Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios") from 9 October until 20
November 2015.[17]

In January 2016, [David Jason](/wiki/David_Jason "David Jason") revealed that
a third series would be produced in 2016. The series began airing on 26
December 2016.[18] Production started in September 2016 with on location for
exterior scenes being shot in Balby Doncaster from 12 September 2016.[19]
[Lynda Baron](/wiki/Lynda_Baron "Lynda Baron") could not reprise her role as
Nurse Gladys Emmanuel as the filming dates clashed with Baron's current
contract with _[EastEnders](/wiki/EastEnders "EastEnders")_.[20]

David Jason announced that a fourth series would be filmed in 2017.[21]
Filming began in September 2017 with David Jason seen on location in Doncaster
with co-star Tim Healy [22]. The series began airing on 28 December 2017.
[23]. Interior scenes were recorded at Pinewood Studios in front of a live-
studio-audience on 7, 14, and 21 October and on the 4, 11, 18, and 24 November
2016.[24] In early 2017 a fourth series was commissioned production started in
August 2017. On location exterior scenes for the fourth series commenced on 11
September 2017 in Doncaster.[25].

In January 2018, it was revealed the show will return for a fifth series late
2018.[26]

[](/wiki/File:Lister_Avenue_in_Balby_\(a_suburb_of_Doncaster_in_the_North_of_England\),_used_for_the_exterior_shots_on_the_BBC_television_sitcom_Open_All_Hours.jpg
"Enlarge")

Lister Avenue in [Balby](/wiki/Balby "Balby") is used for the filming of
_Still Open All Hours_ ; Beautique on the right doubles as Arkwright's

The exterior shots reused the original shop from the series, on Lister Avenue
in [Balby](/wiki/Balby "Balby"), a suburb of [Doncaster](/wiki/Doncaster
"Doncaster"). The shop had to be extensively redressed (for both programmes)
to resemble a traditional corner shop, as it has been a hair salon since 1962.
This process took two days, before filming on location for three consecutive
days.[27]

For the 2013 special, the studio shots were recorded at Dock10 studios at
[MediaCityUK](/wiki/MediaCityUK "MediaCityUK"), Salford Quays. For the first
series, [Teddington Studios](/wiki/Teddington_Studios "Teddington Studios")
were used and the second, third, and fourth series were all recorded at
[Pinewood Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios").

##
Episodes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Still_Open_All_Hours&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Episodes")]

Main article:
[List_of_Still_Open_All_Hours_episodes](/wiki/List_of_Still_Open_All_Hours_episodes
"List of Still Open All Hours episodes")

Twenty-seven episodes of _Still Open All Hours_ , all written by Roy Clarke,
have been produced for the BBC. The show began airing on 26 December 2013 with
an anniversary special of original series, _Open All Hours_. All episodes have
a running time of 30 minutes. Between _Open All Hours_ and _Still Open All
Hours_ , there has been a total of 53 episodes and eight series broadcast
between 1973 and 2018.

## Broadcast and
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Still_Open_All_Hours&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Broadcast and reception")]

The special was broadcast on BBC One on 26 December 2013 and received 9.43m
(39.9% of the audience) viewers according to overnight figures and was the
most watched programme on that day.[28] Final viewing figures showed that it
was watched by 12.23m and was the most watched programme for that week.[29] It
received generally poor reviews from critics. Will Dean of _[The
Independent](/wiki/The_Independent "The Independent")_ called it a "w-w-worthy
[sic] effort" but criticised the attempt to revive the show without the late
[Ronnie Barker](/wiki/Ronnie_Barker "Ronnie Barker").[30] Ben Lawrence of
_[The Telegraph](/wiki/Telegraph_Media_Group "Telegraph Media Group")_ said it
"felt like a relic of another era" criticising the jokes and Jason's
performance.[31] Jacob Mason, writing on the Radio Times website, described
the show as "warmly nostalgic", whilst others noted it as "a fitting tribute
to Ronnie Barker".[32] On 21 November 2014, the BBC confirmed that _Still Open
All Hours_ would return for a full series in 2014. This began airing on 26
December 2014 and finished on 25 January 2015. Series 2 began on the 26th
December 2015 with a run of 6 episodes and finished on 26 January 2016,
Followed by Season 3 which began airing on 26 December 2016 with 7 episodes.

## DVD
releases[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Still_Open_All_Hours&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: DVD releases")]

Although filmed and broadcast in High-definition, no Blu-ray releases have
been announced to date. Series One and the 2013 Christmas Special was released
on DVD on 2 February 2015 by [2 entertain](/wiki/2_entertain "2 entertain").
[33] Series 2 was released on 1 February 2016. Series 3 was released on 13
February 2017. [34]
